body.p: This very useful paper adds helpful insights to the agenda that surrounds clinical academic career development for nurses and allied health professionals. I welcome its publication as it offers some good descriptions of the systemic challenges facing non-medical health professionals who wish to advance research-based practice and competence.

It can be argued, as this paper indeed does, that the necessary architecture is now in place to support career pathways for clinician researchers but the subtle difficulties experienced by those wishing to support the next generation of researchers are multiple and they are well described here. There are also telling and original insights offered from this work into the differences within and between the academic institutions.

The study strongly echoes background consultation work that informed the UKCRC document ‘Developing the best research professionals’ (United Kingdom Clinical Research Collaboration, 2007). During 2006–2007 I had the privilege of providing research support to the consultation that shaped and informed the final document and during that consultation period, while my research team and I were analysing the views of the professions, people who provide services and service leaders, the themes described here were beginning to emerge from those consultations (Jackson and Butterworth, 2007).

This study offers a further, and more detailed description of the landscape into which research policy has to be translated into practice, which is always challenging to clinicians and educators. What is clear from this work is that it is likely that significant numbers of educators who will become the culture carriers for the next generation recognise and have suffered from competing (and often confusing) demands on their time, and they know only too well the barriers that the new generation of clinician researchers face. To carry forward the possibilities offered by a new research career landscape will require some dogged determination for the respondents to this study.

There are lessons from history. This paper is presented during the Centenary celebration year of Florence Nightingale. Often in the face of opposition, the determination she demonstrated in providing data that attested to poor health was critical to changes in care for army personnel. Succeeding generations of health professionals have worked to introduce significant changes to the delivery of services, the education of the professions and now the implementation of a research-based culture in clinical work. While the barriers that are highlighted in this study are significant they are not insurmountable.

The next generation of clinician researchers will look on us kindly if we can take advantage of the possible, they will be disappointed if we succumb to the pressures to sustain the status quo. This work will help us to take some next small steps on a long journey.

bio.p: Prof. Tony Butterworth (PhD, MSc, RNT, RMN, RGN, FMed.Sci, FRCPsych, FRCN, FRSA. FQNI, DSc (hon)) is a qualified mental health and general nurse with experience in hospital and community settings as well as in teaching and research. He became inaugural Chair and Queens Nursing Institute Professor of Community Nursing at the University of Manchester in 1987 where he undertook original and ground breaking research into clinical supervision and psychosocial education for people with schizophrenia. He led a Government review of mental health nursing in 1994 and became General Secretary for WHO Collaborating Centres for Nursing in 1997.

Promoted to Dean of School to succeed the Baroness McFarlane of Llandaff, he later became a Pro-Vice Chancellor for external affairs for the University of Manchester in 1998. During this time he was elected by his peers to be the first Chair of the Council of Deans of Health in 1997.

Tony moved back to the NHS as WDC Chief Executive for Trent in 2001 and he became Director of a Research Centre for Clinical and Academic Workforce Innovation at the University of Lincoln in 2005. He and his team led the UKCRC review of Clinical Academic Careers for Nursing, completed in late 2007. He was elected to be first Chair of the Academy of Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting Research (UK) in 2008.

He is presently working as:
Chair of the Academy of Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting Research (UK).
Non-Executive Director of the NHS Institute for Innovation and Improvement.
Trustee to the Charity – For Dementia and Admiral Nursing.
Visiting Professor to the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Maribor in Slovenia. He has supervised 22 students to the successful completion of their PhDs, authored or co-authored 6 text books and written extensively in peer reviewed journals and the professional press. He developed and leads a post-graduate module on modernisation, patient safety and Improvement for a taught Masters (M.Clin.Res.) degree. He was recently awarded honorary Fellowship of the NHS Institute Faculty of Health Care Innovators.
